title: What is the difference between Louisiana Creole and Louisiana French? - Quora

response.answer_text: I take it you mean linguistically. (If you don't, see Angèle d'Esplechin's answer to What is the difference between Cajun and Creole?) To a non-French speaker, the two languages usually sound the same. The accents and cadence do not noticeably differ. This makes it difficult for Standard French speakers to understand Louisiana Creole, but allows Louisiana French speakers to pick it up fairly easily. Grammatically, however, the two are quite distinct. LC has a subject-verb-object word order; LF tends toward subject-object-verb. There is no counterpart to suis/est. To joli, therefore, is t'es joli. They each have a different set of pronouns. In LC, we say “Mo,” while in LF we say “Je.” To is tu/ti/. Yé is ils/eux-autres. Nouzot and nous-autres, and vouzot and vous-autres, however, sound the same. They are spelled differently because… The two languages have different orthography. LC has a unique orthography that is completely phonetic and uses way more diacritics than LF. LF uses regular French orthography (because, for all its quirks, it is still French). The tenses are different, with LC inserting markers like té and sé before the verb; LF conjugates more or less normally to Standard French. Demonstratives are different. Also, in older varieties of Créole, the difference between feminine and masculine words is ignored, with everything using a masculine article. This is an old feature, and I believe has been replaced by the French use of masculine/feminine différentiation. Some words are different. Gain is avoir. Some words sound the same, but mean something different. Kouri, for example, means to go, not to run, as courir does. This video explains differences as well:  Here is a page that explains LC grammar alongside English: http://louisianacreoledictionary.com/Lesson%20Topics/Grammar.aspx

Louisiana Creole was originally a mixture of the French and Spanish aristocrats in New Orleans. It was later expanded to include Africans in the mix. Louisiana French refers to people of French descent in Louisiana. Most of these people are Cajuns, or Acadians, people displaced from Acadia, an area spanning the Maine-Canada border.
